comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content:
Born 1893 Failsworth, Lancs. The 1901 census records him living at 14 Hardman Street, Failsworth with his parensts Enoch [b.1849 Facit [near Bacup]] and Elizabeth Ann [b.1853 Lees, Oldham], sister Annie [b.1882 Failsworth] and brothers Frank [b.1880 Lees, Oldham], Joseph [b.1885 Failsworth], Harold [b.1887 Failsworth], Harold [b.1887 Failsworth], Charles [b.1890 Failsworth], Thomas [b.1896 Failsworth]. His father is employed as a commercial clerk.
The 1911 census records the family [with the exception of the eldest son, Frank] living at the same address. Percy is employed as an Insurance Clerk. His brothers are all employed as clerks in various industries.
He enlisted in Hollinwood, Lancs. Pte 4580 Manchester Regiment later 52606 King’s [Liverpool] Regiment.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
23-year-old Percy Greaves was reported missing during the Battle for the Ancre Heights, 13-15 November 1916.  2nd Division, under the command of Major General Charles Monro, consisting 5th, 6th and 99th Brigades suffered over 2,900 casualties in this action, fought across a waterlogged, shell blasted, mud-filled battlefield, choked with barbed wire and corpses and impossible to navigate at night.

1st Battalion King's Liverpool Regiment were in 6th Brigade, together with 2nd Battalion South Staffordshires; 13th Battalion Essex; and 17th Battalion Middlesex.  6th Brigade had moved to the Somme area from opposite Vimy ridge in July 1916 and had already been engaged on the Somme in August and September in the fighting for Delville Wood, Waterlot Farm and Guillemont.//

comment._content:
His 1911 home at 14 Hardman Street, Failsworth, still exists.
Here is a screen shot [thumbnail]  of the property.

comment.author: 68061336@N05
comment._content: The Commonwealth War Graves Commission lists the folloowing Rank:Private Service No:52606 Date of Death:Between 13/11/1916 and 15/11/1916 Regiment/Service:The King's (Liverpool Regiment) 1st Bn. Grave ReferenceI. B. 21. CemeterySERRE ROAD CEMETERY No.2 A photo his grave can be found here twgpp.org/information.php?id=3055195

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: During the First World War Two new parks and a memorial were opened to commemorate the 235 men from Failsworth who fell in battle in World War 1. On Sunday 10th June,1923, the Failsworth War Memorial was unveiled. It is surmounted. by a replica in gilded bronze of the winged figure of “Victory” at Naples. The memorial stands in Watchcote Park, the tiny ‘lung’ in a congested district. Designed by Mr J Henry Sellars of Manchester, it takes the form of a cenotaph l3ft 6ins high, and comprises an octagonal shaft mounted on a pedestal in Portland stone. The shaft is fluted on each face in coloured gilt tiles. . THEY DIED IN MANY LANDS . THAT . WE MAY LIVE HERE IN PEACE . REMEMBRANCE . 1914-1918 From the Oldham Standard. 11th June 1923 www.failsworth.info/failsworth/warmemorial.htm
